Favorite reads from local book connoisseurs

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 10:42 a.m. EST December 18, 2014

Story Highlights

  • Picks for fiction books include science fiction, mystery and storylines that spring from history.
  • Non-fiction picks include a creative take on the animal kingdom and a cross-country travelogue.
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Book lists are nearly as prevalent in December as Christmas trees. They come from all directions and often from national media. But this year, The Courier-Journal’s list is culled with the help of Louisville area people who dedicate much of their working and personal lives to books and reading.

Their choices and comments are diverse. The list includes mystery, humor, science fiction, tenderness and tales of courage. There are historical stories told with distinctively different approaches, graphic novels and memoirs.

So read on.

FICTION

“The Bees” by Laline Paull

You will love and root for Flora 717, the novel’s main character. Through masterful and magical storytelling, Laline Paull invites you to experience her world as a lowly worker honey bee. She is different: She talks and is physically bigger and mentally sharper than her caste-mates. She is an outcast with undeniable loyalty to the hive, while harboring a great secret. Her surprising skills and bravery often get her into serious trouble with the Queen’s court. An amazing first novel, the author brilliantly explores beehive colony life in all its regality and drudgery. Recommended for fans of Margaret Atwood’s “The Handmaid’s Tale,” “Clan Apis” by Jay Hosler and T. H. White’s “The Once and Future King.”

— Lisa Sizemore, interim director, Louisville Free Public Library

“Euphoria” by Lily King

I love historical fiction, and the best novels to me are the ones that blend the facts with a certain sizzle — stories that bring you right into the action and give you a better understanding of the events that took place. King has done just that with her latest novel, “Euphoria,” set between the world wars and based on anthropologist Margaret Mead. In 1933, after a major setback in her research in New Guinea, she and her second husband meet up with a man who finds them a new tribe to research, one that is female-dominated and artistic. The three decide to team up together and thus begins an academic, intellectual and passionate adventure that sets into motion events beyond their wildest imaginings. This is a tale of competition and ambition; a love triangle between Mead, her second husband and her eventual third husband; and a bitter fight for fame and acknowledgment for one’s life work. Steamy, fast-paced, insightful and wildly entertaining.

— Johanna Hynes, publishers’ sales representative and bookseller, Carmichael’s Bookstore

“The Invention of Wings” by Sue Monk Kidd

Sue Monk Kidd is back in the magnificent form she showed in her first novel, “The Secret Life of Bees.” In this, her third novel, she starts with the historic character Sarah Moore Grimke, who was both an abolitionist and a strong advocate for women’s rights. The book is loosely based on the life of Sarah Grimke. Kidd adds richly imagined emotional, intellectual and cultural details as well as a cast of believable characters. The most important is a slave girl named Hetty. The story begins when Sarah’s wealthy plantation-owning parents present her with 10-year-old Hetty as a birthday gift. Even at age 11, Sarah is repelled by the idea of owning another human being, but she is far too young to defy her parents and disrupt tradition — that will come later. The story is told in alternating chapters by Sarah and Hetty and follows these two somewhat similar women born into very different circumstances over 35 years as they bond, face challenges and heartbreak, and find their strengths and their voices. “The Invention of Wings” is both a heart-wrenching look at the horrors of slavery and an uplifting portrait of some of the people who dedicated their lives to ending it. The book builds to thrilling conclusion as Sarah risks everything to help Hetty escape from a life of bondage and abuse.

— Carol Besse, co-owner, Carmichael’s Bookstores

“On Such a Full Sea” by Chang-Rae Lee

It’s Baltimore of the future and in this novel called “B-mor.” Our heroine is leading a pleasant upper-middle class life in a structured compound with her loving family until the day her boyfriend is taken. This book chronicles the journey of Fan to find her missing partner in a highly segregated and classist society that isolates its citizens from one another, creating a divided state. Told with haunting vision, this book stuck with me for months after reading it. I could not shake the visions of a lawless countryside and over-regulated cities where life exists in vastly different realities for the residents born to privileged or poverty. That may ring true in our current society. In the wake of Ferguson and the fall of Detroit, this book takes you to a not-too-distant reality that you might see coming.

— Corin Hindenach, bookseller, Carmichael’s Bookstore

“The Parrot Told Me” by Rachael Rawlings

Rachael is a local author, so that alone is a reason to try the book, I think. Then you have the bonus of laughter and thoughtfulness in a quick, endearing story. The story opens with Camille inheriting a neighbor’s African gray parrot. Rachael’s story will sound familiar to those who have parrots, which is a cultural experience all its own. But this book will have you on the edge of your seat as you watch Camille deal with her past while she solves the murder. “The Parrot Told Me” is a wonderful way to spend a cold afternoon and a must-read book if you ever thought you would want to own a parrot.

— Karen Eldridge, owner, Karen’s Book Barn, La Grange

“The Peripheral” by William Gibson

Gibson practically created the genre of cyber-fiction with the classic 1984 novel “Neuromancer.” In “The Peripheral,” he makes an important contribution to what we call maker-fiction. He imagines a plausible future where information can rationally travel through time — even if we and our stuff cannot. Using information, then, a future society can divert the course of our history even when they can’t change their own past. In much the same way we might use a docking station as a peripheral element to our smartphone, activists of the future can use us as peripherals to supplement their own technologies.

— Randy Smith, proprietor, Destinations Booksellers, New Albany, Ind.

“Saga: Book One” by Brian K. Vaughan, illustrated by Fiona Staples. Deluxe hardcover edition containing issues 1 to 18 in the series.

“Saga” is the story of two star-crossed lovers, Marco and Alana, caught in the middle of an intergalactic war, who have also just given birth to their daughter Hazel. While it could be described as “Star Wars” meets “Romeo and Juliet,” the storytelling is fresh and Vaughan creates characters you instantly find yourself rooting for. His writing is witty, thoughtful and at times contains very mature content (not for young readers). Staples’ artwork is beautiful and it is a perfect fit for this book. This deluxe edition also includes bonus sketches from Staples. The series has won many of the comic industry’s highest awards, the Eisner Awards and the Harvey Awards. This year Vaughn received an Eisner Award for best writer. In 2013, “Saga” won a Hugo Award from the World Science Fiction Society for best graphic story.

— Laura Ziegler, assistant manager, Half Price Books, 10220 Westport Road

“Saint Monkey” by Jacinda Townsend

Townsend’s debut novel brings the epoch of the 1950s to life through the trials and triumphs of growing up black in Kentucky and New York in a way that is continually important. The book would appeal to music lovers with its vibrant scenes of the Jazz Age, fans of historical fiction or parents of dreamers. It could serve as a gift for a variety of readers. While Townsend weaves the tale of two friends growing apart through equal first person perspectives, she leaves a haunting understanding of ever-present issues. Townsend was born in Kentucky, practiced law in New York and writes beautifully about both places through the imaginative scope of the 1950s.

— Rachel Short, host of Keep Louisville Literary on Art x FM (artxfm.com)

“Wolf in White Van” by John Darnielle

Pulsating at the core of Darnielle’s debut novel is a subtle mystery: How did our mangled protagonist end up the way he did? But behind and around all that is a more profound pursuit of the meaning inside the current American experience. What is it in this modern life that produces such a deep and profound stricture on existence and promotes such longing and angst? Why do we want so much and need such a clear definition of ourselves and the truth that is embedded inside that struggle? A tale that presents itself as the story of one recluse and his coping mechanism for the tragedy of his own life turns out to be a statement about life itself. “Wolf in White Van” is the best book I’ve read all year, and maybe the best I will read for several years to come.

— Mark Schultz, freelance writer and bookseller, Carmichael’s Bookstore

“The World of Ice and Fire: The Untold History of Westeros and the Game of Thrones” by George R.R. Martin, Linda Antonsson and Elio Garcia

One of the most popular titles this season has been “The World of Ice and Fire.” This illustrated coffee table hardcover book contains a comprehensive history of the Seven Kingdoms. It includes full-color artwork and maps, family trees for the various houses, examinations of the culture of Westeros and more content exclusive to this volume. Martin partnered with the founders of Westeros.org — Elio Garcia and Linda Antonsson — to create the perfect gift for fans of this beloved series.

— Courtney Day, assistant store manager, Barnes & Noble, 801 S. Hurstbourne Parkway

NON FICTION

“Animalium” by Jenny Broom, illustrated by Katie Scott

I have always wanted to have a museum of natural history at my fingertips. I envy the people who can buy a season pass to Chicago’s Field Museum, the American Museum of Natural History in New York or the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. When I saw this book, I felt a bit of that envy fade. Designed as a walk through a natural history museum, this book becomes your personal, professionally curated collection of the best of the animal kingdom. With all of the major species covered, it is great for kids. However, it contains such intricate detail that adults will find something to love on every page. This book is one that will stay on your shelf, on your table or even next to your bed until the pages fall out — and you frame them.

— Corin Hindenach, bookseller, Carmichael’s Bookstore

“Brown Girl Dreaming” by Jacqueline Woodson

I have always loved coming-of-age stories, charting the various paths we travel between childhood and our older selves. Woodson’s “Brown Girl Dreaming” is a gem, a memoir told in poems that weave across the segregated South of the 1960s and a move up to New York. The book meanders through memories and unearths understandings about home and family and the challenge of finding one’s place in the wider world. At an early age, she discovers the power of stories and writing “where you decide what each world and each story and each ending will finally be.” A gift for the budding writer, the poet, and any reader who welcomes a story told with great heart.

— Melissa Bernstrom, associate producer, University of Louisville Kentucky Author Forum

“Carsick” by John Waters

This book made me laugh out loud on almost every page. Waters chronicles his cross-country hitch-hiking tour from Baltimore to San Francisco. The first part is a fictional fantasy of some of the best and worst things he could imagine happening. The second part is the account of the actual journey. The fiction is the raunchy, twisted stuff folks have come to expect from him, but the actual memoir of his trip shows a softer side of the “king of filth.” You realize what an awesome human he actually is. I’ve made the cross-country trip myself several times. He successfully captures the magic of being on the open road and offers poignant profiles of the folks he met along his journey. The journey was one that takes the reader on a tour inside the heart of America but through the lens of the screenwriter and director of “Pink Flamingos.” I loved every second of it.

— Brian Walker, playwright and store manager, Half Price Books, 10220 Westport Road

“Eating on the Wild Side: The Missing Link to Optimum Health” by Jo Robinson

Jo Robinson published “Eating on the Wild Side: The Missing Link to Optimum Health” in 2013, but it was released this year in paperback. In a time when we struggle to realize a true healthy lifestyle, Robinson has given us another tool. Diet and health books are becoming more and more popular because we searching for answers and a way to adapt our lifestyle without necessarily growing our own food. With “Eating on the Wild Side,” you learn to look at food differently so that you can then make better choices for your lifestyle. You will learn about nutritional values, why what was good for our ancestors has been altered and the good alternatives now. If you are interested in living a healthier life, you should definitely have Robinson’s “Eating on the Wild Side” in your library.

— Karen Eldridge, owner, Karen’s Book Barn, La Grange

“Embattled Capital: Frankfort Kentucky in the Civil War” by James M. Prichard

This newly released book comprehensively covers Kentucky’s state capital, Frankfort, during the turbulent Civil War. Frankfort was the only Union state capital to be captured by the Confederate States Army. Well researched and documented, “Embattled Capital” gives the reader much forgotten history. Also it includes is a roster of both Union and Confederate soldiers from Franklin County, a boon to those who study family histories. With photographs and maps, this book might be just the surprise for the history buff on your list.

— Elaine Munsch, bookseller, Barnes & Noble, 801 S. Hurstbourne Parkway

“How to be a Victorian: A Dawn-to-Dusk Guide to Victorian Life” by Ruth Goodman

Are you addicted to reading Victorian era novels or watching BBC period-drama series? Can’t get enough of the stories in “Victoria & Albert” “North & South,” “Jane Eyre,” “Wives and Daughters” and “Daniel Deronda”? In this very accessible book, historian Ruth Goodman satiates any curiosity you might have about the behind-the-scenes lives of the characters, as the book explores the daily life of a variety of classes during England’s Victorian era. Each chapter covers a range of subjects, such as personal grooming, housework, education, entertainment, meals and nearly every other aspect of life. Recommended for fans of “What Jane Austen Ate and Charles Dickens Knew: From Fox Hunting to Whist — the Facts of Daily Life in Nineteenth-Century England.”

— Lisa Sizemore, interim director, Louisville Free Public Library

“Loitering: New and Collected Essays” by Charles D’Ambrosio

Thousands of books were published this year, but none so inventive and creative as “Loitering.” Over a decade ago, D’Ambrosio, a regular contributor to The New Yorker, Paris Review and Zoetrope, published a little book of essays called “Orphans.” It quickly earned a cult following among its readers. They passed it on to friends only after securing a guarantee of its return. Finally, D’Ambrosio has published those original 11 essays along with new and uncollected work into a volume so wild and varied, it will make your head spin. With subjects as diverse as Native American whale hunting, a Pentecostal haunted house, J.D. Salinger, Mary Kay Letourneau and the suicide attempts of both his brothers, D’Ambrosio brings you unlikely tales of compassion and an understanding for sometimes unsavory and utterly jarring characters. This is a book you read for its writing, so have a pen handy. You’ll want to underline sentence after sentence in hopes of committing them to memory. This is a book you read to expand your insight to the world, and your unlikely connections to the characters in it.

— Johanna Hynes, publishers’ sales representative and bookseller, Carmichael’s Bookstore

“The Mockingbird Next Door: Life with Harper Lee” by Marja Mills

Like countless readers, Harper Lee has been a significant literary influence in my life since age 12 when I first read “To Kill a Mockingbird.” I’m an unapologetic fan (one of my children is even named in honor of a character) and not alone in admitting fascination with the highly evolved intelligence and deft sensibility of the book’s author. Now comes “The Mockingbird Next Door,” which may want us to believe it is a biography of Lee. But it isn’t. In actuality, it’s a memoir by Mills, who crafted a friendship with Lee and her sister Alice. Mills left her newspaper job in Chicago to move to the sisters’ hometown of Monroeville, Ala., the very place that inspired the fictional town of Maycomb in Lee’s famous novel. In spite of (or because of) the controversy surrounding the release of Mills’ book this year, I gravitated toward it in hopes of gaining insight about the backstory of “To Kill a Mockingbird.” Mills delivers in this regard — even as she inadvertently demonstrates precisely why Harper Lee has long had good reason to be skeptical about trusting outsiders who trespass upon her deep need for privacy. This is a book that “To Kill a Mockingbird” enthusiasts can appreciate, even if they have to read between the lines.

— Kate Larken, editor, publisher, pounder, MotesBooks

“On Immunity” by Eula Biss

I was particularly interested in this book because I was diagnosed with pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, this past summer. Pertussis is one of the childhood diseases that is making a strong comeback due in part to a growing number of parents not immunizing their children for common childhood diseases. Biss begins this smart, scrupulously researched and highly thought-provoking book by describing her own fears as a new mother. It’s a dilemma any new parent can relate to — how do I keep my child safe from the myriad dangers in the world. From these broad fears that we will be unable to protect our children, she zeroes in on the topic of immunizations and her struggles with having her child vaccinated. From there, she expands on the idea of inoculation and uses it as a platform to delve into a much more wide-ranging and fascinating discussion on social systems, our obligations to the community in which we live, and how and why some untruths gain wide traction in society. “On Immunity” was chosen by The New York Times Book Review as one of The Ten Best Books of 2014. I couldn’t agree more.

— Carol Besse, co-owner, Carmichael’s Bookstores

“Preparing the Ghost: An Essay Concerning the Giant Squid and Its First Photographer” by Matthew Gavin Frank

I have to admit the first time I read this title was in manuscript form. Unfortunately, Norton (Liveright) with all its commercial might snapped it up before I could even blink. The book combines what I’ve always loved about the modern essay: innovation in form, close attention to language (the author is a poet, too), and a hard-to-beat subject. Obsession with a sea monster drives Frank to an island off the coast of Canada, where he follows the footsteps of the also obsessed 19th century photographer and man-of-the-cloth Moses Harvey. Long ago, the corpse of a giant squid washed up on the beach and Moses was there to drag this water-logged, phenomenally heavy creature back to his house via horse and cart, then “store” it in his bathroom until his wife finally revolted. Along the way, we have a history of Newfoundland, inventive scene setting, a discussion of myth, science, ice cream — and, of course, the amazing giant cephalopod in all its imagined and actual detail. It’s a wonderfully entertaining, edifying read.

— Sarah Gorham, president and editor-in-chief, Sarabande Books Inc.

“Rebel Yell: The Violence, Passion, and Redemption of Stonewall Jackson” by S.C. Gwynne

Though I consider myself above-average in Civil War knowledge, I never felt drawn to Confederate Gen. Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson. Historian S.C. Gwynne, however, brought both the man and his significant impact on our country’s most divisive era to my attention. Nothing about Jackson’s station in life predicted how critical his personality and intellect would be to the South’s military survival. (He was a pedantic professor at Virginia Military Institute and not particularly well thought of there.) “Rebel Yell” adequately explains how Jackson’s campaigns allowed Confederate forces to achieve victory upon victory — and it even tells the story of just where the phrase “rebel yell” came from.

— Randy Smith, proprietor, Destinations Booksellers, New Albany, Ind.

“Syllabus: Notes from an Accidental Professor” by Lynda Barry

Until recently, I’ve not invested much time with books that are more illustration than words. Graphic novels hold no appeal for me. However, Lynda Barry’s strange, brave works prove the exception. I read several of Barry’s collections this year, after a literary friend enlightened me that they’re more than mere comics or cartoons. Thus, I was primed for “Syllabus: Notes from an Accidental Professor” when it fell into my hands as a gift. Barry’s crude visual style can, admittedly, be off-putting at first. But readers soon understand how perfectly her odd illustrations match the complicated subjects of her commentaries. Interestingly, and unlike her previous work, “Syllabus” demonstrates how Barry adapted her quirky, razor-sharp method of cutting to the quick of topics (social, psychological and every other kind) for use in academic endeavors. While teaching a multidisciplinary course, Barry overcame reluctance, surrendered to her experimental instincts and created unique ways to inspire her students to challenge their own insecurities (those familiar self-imposed limits of capability) so they might try a new brand of thinking, seeing, discovering. Best of all, any reader can do the same just by sitting with “Syllabus,” opening the mind to possibility and allowing whatever was previously unimagined a place to play.

— Kate Larken, editor, publisher, pounder, MotesBooks
